briefOverview: Revelation to Joseph Smith and Sidney Rigdon giving reassurance about their families, direction for preaching by the Spirit, defined complementary roles, and a promise of Zion’s eventual redemption.
summary: The Lord assures Joseph and Sidney that their families are safe in His hands and calls them to continue preaching in the eastern regions where He has prepared receptive people. He promises to give them words in the very moment they need, commanding them to speak in His name with meekness and solemnity so the Holy Ghost can confirm their message. The Lord appoints Sidney as a spokesman and Joseph as a revelator, granting power to Joseph in testimony and to Sidney in expounding scripture. He bids them rejoice in their journey with the assurance of His presence. Concerning Zion, He declares that it will be redeemed after a period of chastening and that all things will work together for good to the upright and to the sanctification of the Church. He specifically notes that Orson Hyde and John Gould are in His hands and will be saved if they keep His commandments, and that He will raise up a pure, righteous people.
externalContext: This revelation is dated to October 1833 and is traditionally located at Perrysburg, New York, during a short mission Joseph Smith and Sidney Rigdon undertook toward Upper Canada. At the time, Latter-day Saint communities in Missouri (often called “Zion”) were experiencing escalating conflict with local residents that would culminate in forced expulsion later that year. Joseph and Sidney were anxious about their families in Kirtland, Ohio, prompting the revelation’s initial reassurance. Early Latter-day Saint missions commonly emphasized preaching without elaborate preparation, relying on extemporaneous inspiration and the confirmation of the Holy Spirit.
externalReferences: The charge to speak without premeditation echoes Jesus’ instruction to His disciples (Matthew 10:19-20; Luke 12:11-12) and aligns with similar counsel in Doctrine and Covenants 84:85. The assurance “I have much people in this place” closely parallels the Lord’s message to Paul in Corinth (Acts 18:9-10). The delineation of roles—Sidney as spokesman and Joseph as revelator—recalls the Moses–Aaron pattern, where Aaron served as Moses’ mouthpiece (Exodus 4:14-16). The promise that “all things shall work together for good” reflects the sentiment of Romans 8:28, applied here to those who walk uprightly and to the Church’s sanctification.
practicalQuestions: When I teach or speak, how can I better rely on the Spirit in the very moment while maintaining meekness and solemnity?
What does it look like in my context to declare things in the Lord’s name rather than in self-promotion or anxiety?
How can I partner with others whose gifts complement mine, honoring distinct roles without rivalry?
In seasons of uncertainty about loved ones, how can I entrust them to God’s care and continue in my callings?
What does faithful response to chastening look like so that it leads to purification and collective sanctification?
uncertainAreas: “This place” and “this eastern land” may refer to a specific locality (likely Perrysburg or the broader region en route to Upper Canada), but the exact geographic scope within the text is not explicit. The precise circumstances of Orson Hyde and John Gould at the moment of this revelation are not detailed here, making their referenced situation partly reliant on external historical sources.
